question: 濡れ衣
sourceMnemonic: Ah yes, <kanji>wet</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for <vocabulary>false accusations</vocabulary>. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.
sourceReadingMnemonic: This word is made up of the reading from <ja>濡れる</ja> and the rendaku version of the <ja>きぬ</ja> reading of <ja>衣</ja>. You learned this reading in the <ja>衣</ja> vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "<reading>gi</reading>ve <reading>new</reading> (<ja>ぎぬ</ja>) clothes to me!"
